title: 112_hr1077
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cooking Helps Elevate Futures Act" or the "CHEF Act". The Congress acknowledges the high number of individuals in prison in the United States, with over 2,000,000 incarcerated in 2008. Each year, more than 650,000 inmates are released back into society, facing challenges like lack of job skills and high risk of recidivism due to insufficient support services. According to a 12-year study by the Federal Bureau of Prisons, job skills and training obtained through prison programs reduce recidivism rates. Inmates who participated in vocational training were 24% less likely to reoffend and 14% more likely to be employed post-release. Culinary training is effective for increasing employment rates among former inmates due to high demand in the food service industry, with over 1.5 million culinary positions available in the US in 2008. Establishment of pilot program. The Attorney General will establish a pilot program to provide culinary arts training and job placement assistance for Federal inmates in 10 different correctional facilities across the United States. The curr_chunk discusses the percentage of the State's population that are Federal inmates, their recidivism rate, and unemployment rate after release from a Federal correctional facility. The term "continental United States" is defined as a State (other than Alaska and Hawaii) and the District of Columbia. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, will establish eligibility requirements for Federal inmates to participate in a pilot program. The Attorney General may contract with entities to provide culinary training and job placement assistance for inmates in the program. The Attorney General will submit a report to Congress detailing the participation, certification, job placement, employment duration, recidivism rate, and disciplinary incidents of Federal inmates in a pilot program. The Attorney General will report to Congress on the participation, certification, job placement, employment duration, recidivism rate, and disciplinary incidents of Federal inmates in a pilot program, comparing incidents involving program participants to those who did not participate. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the fiscal years 2012 through 2017 to fund the pilot program.
